data.title: Compile android template error on Windows
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, scons 2.4.1, MSVC 14, 89132224a651c0e0d4121270f63decb9a678ff88

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

```
modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function register_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'register_chibi_types()'
modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function register_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'register_cscript_types()'
modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function register_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'register_dds_types()'
... lots of "register_module_something()"

modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function unregister_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'unregister_chibi_types()'
modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function unregister_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'unregister_cscript_types()'
modules\libmodules.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.a(register_module_types.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.o):register_module_types.cpp:function unregister_module_types(): error: undefined reference to 'unregister_dds_types()'
... lots of "unregister_module_something()"
... and lots of "webp, VP8, TestGDScript::test" things

collect2.exe: error: ld returned 1 exit status

=====
scons: *** [bin\libgodot.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.so] Error 1
scons: building terminated because of errors.
```

Compiling for windows tool and templates are fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
`scons -j 4 platform=android colored=yes tools=no target=release_debug`

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: find_node broken?
data.body:
Ubuntu 16.04 lts 64 bit
Godot 2.1 stable

Please see the screenshot. Using `get_node( "/root/World/ground" )` works, but using e.g. `get_tree().get_root().find_node("ground")` doesn't. Which surprises me based on the find_node docs.

![gd](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/77176/19416503/2ad13ae8-9347-11e6-957a-1c656d9d8126.png)

data.title: debugger not showing correct script
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.04 lts 64 bit
Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I have 
- a main_scene X that is my own looper to step the game through the individual game levels.
- a level template that is a full world with camera and objects and player.
- scripts for the level template are not external files, they are inlined in the .tscn file.

my main_scene X loads the template like this:
- var s = load("res://level.tscn")
- var l = s.instance()
- add_child( l )

when add_child( l ) happens, it looks like the new instance really gets set up e.g. the "onready vars" happen. my problem is that when the debugger breaks on an error/bug in my code, the debugger often gets confused and doesn't show me the right script. 

I assume it is confused because there are many scripts inlined inside level.tscn, and because the scene was programmatically instantiated. but i dunno.

data.title: Kinematic2d (Collision Layer/Mask)
data.body:
Ubuntu 16.04, Godot (git clone)

Hi, as the title I seems docs are missing when comes to collision Layer and Mask
but as for as I can understand the mask scans for collision in layer something like 

OBJ1Mask == OBJ2Layer

so, this is my current condition

const BULLET_COLLISION_LAYER = 5
const FIGHTER_COLLISION_LAYER = 6
const ENEMY_COLLISION_LAYER  = 7

const BULLET_COLLISION_MASK  = ENEMY_COLLISION_LAYER
const FIGHTER_COLLISION_MASK  = ENEMY_COLLISION_LAYER
const ENEMY_COLLISION_MASK = FIGHTER_COLLISION_LAYER

hmmm, now as per the condition Bullet should not collide with the FIGHTER, But it does

data.title: Have "Create" and "Add" options instead of "Add script" on node right click menu
data.body:
Adding a script on a node can be done in two ways:
- Creating one
- Adding an existing one

But there is only one option in the right-click menu of a node in the hierarchy. Could we have the same options as in the inspector?

data.title: (Feature request) Configure the template added to each script
data.body:
Just thought it would be nice to be able to configure the template for each type of script, just to automatize something the programmer want on every script, or just to get rid of the current template.

I just wonder if it would be best to handle this as a Project Setting or as an Editor Setting (IMO a project setting would handle it well).

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When I drag Godot editor from MacBook Pro retina screen to my secondary monitor (full hd) it becomes weird, it gets very large and because of it cropped inside the window area, when I bring it back to retina screen its background becomes white going back  to normal after rescaling window.

Just launch Godot on a dual monitor setup as described above and drag the editor from retina to the secondary screen

data.title: Move most "drivers" as toggleable "modules" and split their thirdparty libraries in an own tree
data.body:
Should address most of #6157.

While working on this, I got a bit more scons experience and could isolate most modules (and some of the remaining drivers) in their own environment, which means that their necessary defines and include paths can now be passed without polluting the global env. It means we could drop some dirty hacks we put in several thirdparty sources to hardcode include paths so that they match our repo, etc. There is also no more risk of confusion between headers of different projects that share the same name.

Most libraries that are typically available on a Linux distribution can be unbundled (i.e. you can just delete their `thirdparty/$libname` folder and build with `libname=system`). Some more work will be needed to put some order in the scons options as it's a bit messy now, but I'll do all this in a later PR. Currently only `platform/x11` has instructions to link against system libraries when `system` options are chosen, but it could be extended for other relevant platforms.

To disable a module, the syntax is now automatic: `module_$module_enable=yes|no` (see `scons --help`). We might have to document this a bit better in the official compilation docs, and also rename the current arguments I used to specify the use of builtin or system libraries for more clarity (e.g. `openssl=system` could become `system_openssl=yes` or `builtin_openssl=no`.

All in all, this was quite a lot of work and I might have made a few mistakes along the road. Therefore I'd appreciate:
- extensive testing on all supported platforms and whenever possible also with some exotic options (e.g. disabling an important module and check that the rest of the engine still builds and runs ok).
- code review especially of the various SCsub files.

That should be a first step towards making it **much** easier to maintain our thirdparty code, and also to get Godot packaged in Linux distributions.

data.title: Can't not catch event from Button under BottomDock(plugin)/GraphEdit/GraphNode
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.2 alpha (6c0be2c017e605c2106823e80e5aaa78fc68aba5)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Can't not catch event from Button under BottomDock(plugin)/GraphEdit/GraphNode

**Steps to reproduce:**
- from running scene, Button pressed event can be catched.
- from dock, never catch.
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8281454/19395282/d3e94f6a-9277-11e6-8154-86b6d650d094.png)

**graphedit_test.gd**

``` gdscript
tool
extends EditorPlugin

var dock

func _enter_tree():
    dock = preload("res://addons/addon_graphedit_test/GraphEdit.tscn").instance()
    add_control_to_bottom_panel(dock, "GraphEdit Test")

func _exit_tree():
    remove_control_from_bottom_panel(dock)
    dock.free()
```

**graphedit_test_scn.gd**

``` gdscript
extends GraphEdit

func _ready():
    get_node("GraphNode/Button").connect("pressed", self, "on_button")

func on_button():
    get_node("GraphNode/Button").set_text("clicked!!!")
```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[godot_plugin_graphedit.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/529983/godot_plugin_graphedit.zip)

data.title: Drop nedmalloc which is apparently not used anymore
data.body: The header that was included in the winrt and windows platforms was incapacitated by the `NEDMALLOC_ENABLED` define, and nothing defines it anymore, so it's likely an obsolete driver that was forgotten.

data.title: Improvements on the Keyboard action handling
data.body:
With the current input action system, if you press a `modifier + key` and there is no action registered for that combination no action gets pressed.
Even if there was one which had that `key` without modifier.

E.g.:

```
ActionMap

forward = W
left = A
right = D
shoot = Shift
```

If at some point I'm holding `Shift` to shoot, I cannot move (because the input event won't be `W` but `Shift+W`). This forces the dev to declare ActionMap this way:

```
forward = W, Shift+W
left = A, Shift+A
right = D, Shift+D
shoot = Shift
```

Which is annoying and hard to maintain if you have a good number of controls and are using one or two modifiers.

My proposal is to handle modifier this way:
- Check if `Modifier+Key` is an action:
  - If yes, press that action
  - Else, check if there is an action which is just `Key`
    - If yes, press that action

I can start working on a PR if there is interest in this.
Any comment?

data.title: Allow even more freedom for line breaks in GDScript
data.body:
GDScript already allows newlines inside arrays and maps, now also inside function calls among other new places thanks to #6694.

It would be nice to allow them in more places like at either side of binary operators (arithmetic, assignment, boolean).

I'm calling on @bojidar-bg here since he has this stuff fresh on his mind. ;)

EDIT: Before/after dot (method/property access) would be nice too.

data.title: Ability to name root node of imported asset scene after its filename
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Any

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
having to rename the root node of a imported scene can get tedious when dealing with lots of scenes or scenes that get updated over time. This can lead to issues if you have code/nodes that depend on some form of naming convention. I think that having a check box in the import settings to rename the root node to the same as the source file name should help alleviate some of the headache. We usually name the source file in a manner that represents what it contains anyway.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Remove speex support, it is obsoleted by opus
data.body:
As mentioned by upstream, Xiph.Org [0]:

> The Speex codec has been obsoleted by Opus. It will continue to be
> available, but since Opus is better than Speex in all aspects,
> users are encouraged to switch.

We discussed this on IRC with @reduz and he was in favour of dropping this driver.
This is one of the compatibility breakages we'll have to document for 3.0.

[0] http://www.speex.org/

data.title: Some suggestions for Label and RichTextLabel
data.body:
I'm in a fork in the road with my project which is rather bothersome.

There's dialogue in my game. Standard stuff. For that, I use a Label so that I can add shadows, custom colors, etc However, there are pieces of dialogue that would have a greater impact on the player if we could add italic and bold font styles in some words, so I consider switching to RichTextLabel.

That's the thing: I have to juggle between one another just to find out which one of them would suit me best. That's a problem.

So, I have a few suggestions.

These are about **Label**:
- "Shadow as outline" has an integer slider setting that does _nothing_ but add or remove the outline (that's because [the code in Label grabs a boolean instead of an integer](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/scene/gui/label.cpp#L88)). An improvement to this would be to use an integer and have a thickness level of the outline
- Export `visible_characters` since we only have `percent_visible` in the editor.

Here are other suggestions; these are optional but highly appreciated: having shared features so that when switching from one another, there would be less broken code. Features like:
- `add_text()` for Label
- `set_scroll_active()`for Label
- `set_text()` for RichTextLabel. Either swap `set_bbcode()`'s name or have a method that just adds raw text without checking if BBCode is on.
- `percent_visible` attributes for RichTextLabel

I hope this isn't asking for too much. I may make a Pull Request, but I'm not sure if I have the time.

data.title: Add rectangle shape option to ParticleAttractor2D
data.body:
ParticleAttractor2D allows quick cheap effects in addition to particle system, but it can also be used as a particle... rejector(?).

Actually is possible to do this at most:

![gparticles](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/19352539/777cbdd0-9136-11e6-89a2-3d7b511ac524.gif)

You can see the negative attractor over the modulated godot icon, useful for fixed things like floor below torches or hitboxes but not usefull to use on a walls or floor.
If we get the option to add a at least a rectangle shape instead of a circle, it could be used to create some effects like collisions on walls with no complex collision system involved.
